title: Too much CDR!
body:
There is far too much CDR itemization in the game...  Let's remove CDR from:
{{item:3156}} {{item:3194}} {{item:3147}} {{item:3812}}{{item:3083}} 
We can buff them in other ways if/as needed.

Let's rework {{item:3508}} to always give only 10% CDR along with some new non-CDR-related replacement passive.

If marksmen and assassins want CDR, they can go out of their way and make significant sacrifices to build it or bring CDR runes. They can still situationally get CDR from items like: {{item:3158}} {{item:3142}} {{item:3078}}{{item:3508}} 

Also, {{item:3071}} should only give 10% CDR, but cleaves should stack up to 10 x 3% (from 6 x 4%) for a total maximum of 30% armor reduction.  Melee auto-attacks should provide 2 cleave stacks each.  This will further discourage marksmen from building BC to replace lost CDR itemization.  Marksmen/assassins will still benefit from their juggernaut/fighter allies shredding more enemy armor with BC.

Also, maybe lower {{item:3110}} to 10% CDR and buff its aura to 20% attack speed reduction.  It's a cool supportive tank item, but it seems to have become more and more rarely built as CDR has become more prevalent.  I think it's too hard to fit 20% CDR on a single item slot into a tank build nowadays.  Also, the aura size should be more visible for allies and enemies (perhaps a faint line of particles resembling the aurora borealis or snow flurries on the edge).

Supports, supportive/true tanks, and maybe mages (at full build) should be the only classes reliably capping 40% CDR every game.  AP assassins should really have better access to CDR than AD assassins if they choose to build it ({{item:3100}} {{item:3152}} {{item:3157}}) since they can't fall back on autoattacks to finish a fight.  Also, AP sacrifices more to bring CDR glyphs because glyphs are AP's primary rune type.

First off, I agree that cdr is a bit too easy to pick up.  However, I also feel like removing it from too many items leaves certain classes of champs without the ability to even attempt to build for cdr if they want to.

Most notably, tanks and ADCs/AD bruisers struggled with being able to get more than 10 or 20% cdr, as the stat simply didn't exist on that many tank or AD items.  I think Riot went a bit overboard by adding CDR to everything, but I also think they wanted to allow more champs to get cdr easier - and allow for different paths to do so.  That being said, it feels like you can get a significant amount of cooldown just by building what you want to anyway, which doesn't feel like a good solution.

I don't blindly hate any champion, but you must know that Riven is considered one of the most snowbally and frustrating to play against as a bad matchup...  Since it's become so convenient for Riven to reach 40% CDR once she's already snowballing, the windows to fight back against her have shrunk considerably in worst case scenarios, leaving bad matchups against her even worse.  Would you consider that it might be healthier if she weren't balanced around easily capping CDR, perhaps in exchange for better options versus her hard counters?  Riven is a popular champion with a devoted playerbase.  Riot wouldn't leave her unviable if reducing AD fighter CDR itemization disproportionately hurt her winrates across the board.  For the most part, less plentiful CDR itemization should create decision making.  You could take scaling CDR runes to be less of a lane bully in exchange for a stronger lategame and still cap CDR for example.  If your matchup allows you to get boots of Lucidity, then that would be another option.  Building Youmoo's would be a third option.  Building Warrior's Machete in her jungle off-role would also provide CDR.  I don't think that Riven or other AD fighters should necessarily reliably reach 40% CDR in their standard build though.  They can be balanced around getting other strengths in their standard builds.  I didn't suggest specific buffs for {{item:3812}} {{item:3156}} but you can feel free to suggest what they would need in exchange for losing CDR.

> [{quoted}](name=Cant Hold Me Now,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=59g2WA9z,comment-id=000a00000000,timestamp=2017-08-12T00:48:38.034+0000)

Frozen Heart is one of the worst rush items for a tank, and only certain tanks can use Iceborn (which isn't even a full tank item, that's got damage on it). Keep in mind that many other top's are AD, and if you plan to survive early game at all, you're not allowed CDR until your 3rd or 4th item.
> 

If we're talking about purely utility/CC tanks, then they are hardly playable without building damage in a solo lane role because they have poor dueling and waveclearing.  When a true tank goes into a solo lane, they must build in a way that makes them somewhat self-sufficient, so in a solo lane environment, {{item:3025}} is a real tank item (often combined with {{item:3068}}) even though other non-tanks, like Ezreal, will sometimes use it.  Solo laning tanks are the primary users that the item is designed for, and it happens to fill a lot of the CDR cap.  After laning, a top lane tank can also get CDR from supportive tank items {{item:3800}} {{item:3109}} if they want since they'll be filling a supportive role in teamfighting anyways.  If they want to forsake CDR for pure tank stats (probably a bad idea in most cases) then they don't need to get 40% CDR in their build, but it wouldn't be too difficult if they want to build CDR.  If you think about it, it's really quite difficult not to overcap CDR as a tank even in top lane.  If you get {{item:3025}}{{item:3068}}  to help with laning, then you decide you want to get {{item:3083}} {{item:3065}} (these two items often go together) then you're already at 40% CDR, which discourages picking up {{item:3800}} for example even though your team might need the help engaging.  By putting CDR on every item, it actually limits freedom in building.  We should need to plan to get capped CDR if we choose to build for it.

For {{item:3110}}, I am primarily considering bot-lane-support tanks since top-laners often prefer {{item:3025}} for the reasons outlined above.  As a bot-lane support tank, it is really very difficult to avoid overcapping CDR, considering {{item:2303}} {{item:3107}} is already 20% CDR, so if you don't want to overcap then you can't pick {{item:3110}} with any other items which contain CDR even though there are so many options that a tanky support might want ({{item:3109}} {{item:3800}} {{item:3065}}  {{item:3050}} {{item:3060}} to name just a few).  If {{item:3110}} gave only 10% CDR in exchange for compensation buffs, then players could buy it and still pick a fourth item containing CDR without overcapping.

Looking back at this after all these years, since somehow this thread has been resurrected, here's how I feel I would rebalance CDR if I had the power to change it now:

20% CDR:
{{item:3110}} {{item:3040}} {{item:3042}}

15% CDR: 
{{item:3110}} {{item:3003}} {{item:3004}} {{item:3078}} {{item:3025}} {{item:3115}}

10% CDR: 
{{item:3101}} {{item:3158}} {{item:3071}} {{item:3142}} {{item:3905}} {{item:3056}} {{item:3102}} {{item:3157}} {{item:3174}} {{item:3024}} {{item:3050}} {{item:3147}} {{item:3100}} {{item:3098}} {{item:3092}} {{item:3096}} {{item:3069}} {{item:3401}} {{item:3161}} {{item:3107}} {{item:2065}} {{item:3504}} {{item:3800}} {{item:3108}} {{item:3222}} {{item:1402}} {{item:1412}} {{item:3152}} {{item:3802}} {{item:3114}} {{item:3285}} {{item:3030}} {{item:3508}}

0% CDR:
{{item:3194}} [Most items losing CDR would be compensated.  Adaptive Helm could receive increased MR for example.]

No more Haste passive on {{item:3802}} or items built from it.

{{item:3070}} gives 5% CDR.  Items built from Tear of the Goddess grant stats from both mana and over-capped CDR (replacing Transcendence rune).

{{item:3110}} builds out of {{item:3070}} + {{item:3024}} + {{item:3082}} and transforms into an upgraded version when Awe is fully stacked.  Awe grants bonus health.  The upgraded version has a stronger, ramping-up aura which can be toggled on, costing mana each second.

{{item:3004}} builds out of {{item:3070}} + {{item:3101}}, gaining its Shock passive (reduced to 1.5% mana on-hit) before upgrading to {{item:3042}} (allowing the full 3% mana on-hit after upgrade).  Because it would no longer build from {{item:1037}}, it would provide less AD, and the recipe change would make it somewhat more expensive.  Manamune would offer a way for mana-gated AD champions to continue building CDR, while resourceless AD champions would have considerably less access to CDR than before.  CDR capping doesn't need to be a super common thing for every champion class, and compensating some items with other strengths, like increased defensive stats, could help improve the game pace.

Transcendence rune is removed (now part of Awe passive) and it is replaced by a Spell Weaving or Expose Weakness rune (just give it a 'Sorcery' sounding name, like Blighting Curse, and give it synergy with DOT and AOE).

Also if Magic Resistance is increased on many items to compensate for reduced CDR on them, there will be room for a new Sorcery keystone tailored to DPS APCs.  Deathfire Touch can make a return as a rune that reduces immediate ability damage dealt in exchange for a larger amount of delayed damage over time.  This will allow players to give up instant burst potential in order to deal DOT DPS.  For example, the keystone could convert 30% of damage that would be dealt by abilities into a burn over 4 seconds that deals 55% of the original ability damage.  This would result in the ability doing 125% in total but spread out over a longer period.  Squishy targets would normally die within 4 seconds of fighting, so this mostly impacts fighting frontliners, hence why this addition to the game would fit with increased availability of Magic Resistance on frontliner items.

I personally find it frustrating to have so much CDR from an itemization perspective. I'm a  mid main, and I wont even go into how efficient LUDENS ECHO is and how it's the Black Cleaver of mid lane... if you're a burst mage you ALWAYS build it first no matter what because it gives you EVERYTHING a mage needs unlike any other item (extra scaling burst dmg, wave clear, 20%CDR, mana item, HIGH AP) Damn, I said this wasn't about Luden's Echo ( or Black Cleaver...)

Anyways. It's DIFFICULT to not have a build that goes over 40% CDR. It's a crappy feeling every game.  Absolute Focus being weaker recently, and 10% CDR in the rune stats, compounds the situation. Although I often take Absolute Focus over Transcendence, I can't see myself trading 10% CDR for 9AP...
Ludens ECHO plus the 10% CDR from runes is already 30%, so pick your 10% item carefully.  Zhonyas?  Banshees? Hextech item? Twin Shadows? Lich Bane?Maybe you're a AP bruiser who wants Spirit Visage. I find it ridiculous an optimal build can't have more than one these item's and Luden's together.
After boots, your other 3 items HAVE to be Void Staff, Rabadons, Liandries, Rylais, Morrelonomicon, or Mejais.

Maybe you're playing ARAM and want some weird itemization but often can't because it's ALWAYS over 40% CDR. 
Tanks have it EVEN WORSE. Pretty much CAN'T build Black Cleaver and Frozen Gauntlet together, because your MR item will put you over the cap. And I don't think you're running Transcendence as a tank, so you dont even have the chance to benefit from the extra adaptive force. 

Overall... ALL the CDR feels bad.

P.S. Why are Ionian Boots even an item even more? If it wasn't for the summoner spell buff, they'd be COMPLETELY obsolete. Even the traditional support characters that would RUSH these boots don't because of excess CDR in every item. They're just better off with literally any other item. (Sorcerer boots for brand lux ect. Even tank boots are better than ionian boots for beefier supports.  Swiftness/mobi boots are almost always good on supps)
